talk.start.para: asked the Minister for External Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: Does Article 10 of the Agreement between Australia and the United States of America concerning the Status of United States Forces in Australia provide that the Australian Government shall permit the establishment of United States commissaries in Australia in accordance with arrangements between the appropriate authorities of the two Governments?

Is it provided that goods for use in or sale by a commissary shall be free of import duty, excise duty and sales tax and that commissaries shall be exempt from Australian licensing requirements, fees and taxes?

Are the United States authorities required to co-operate closely with Australian authorities to ensure the observance of the arrangements applicable to a commissary and to prevent resale on the local market of duty or tax free goods sold by a commissary and any other abuses of privileges exercisable through a commissary?
In particular, are the United States authorities required strictly to police personal quotas in respect of the purchase of duty or tax free goods?
Does 'commissary' under the Article mean a commissary, military sales exchange, officers' club, enlisted men's club or like facility?
What steps are being taken, or will be taken, to prevent resale on the local market of duty or tax free goods?
Can he say what personal quotas are, or will be imposed by the United States authorities in respect of the purchase of duty or tax free goods, and how they will be policed pursuant to the Agreement?

Is it an abuse of the privileges set out in Article 10 for a person entitled to privileges to purchase duty free goods on behalf of a person not so entitled? If so, what steps are taken to prevent this?
Is it a fact that breaches of the Agreement and improper resales are taking place at Exmouth Gulf? If so, what is being done to stop these abuses?
What Customs or police supervision is carried out, or will be carried out, in respect of these activities?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.label: 1 to 5.
item.para: Yes.

item.label: 6 to 8.
item.para: Approval has been given by the Australian Government for the establishment of a commissary at the United States Naval Communication Station, North West Cape. The patrons for whom facilities of the commissary may be afforded are persons who are, or are dependants of, members of the United States Forces or of the civilian component, who are officially attached to or officially visiting the Station.

In compliance with the terms of Article 10 of the Status of Forces Agreement, measures were agreed between the appropriate authorities of the United States and Australian Governments for the prevention of abuses in the commissary's operations. These include the quota restrictions and specific controls to prevent resale of commissary purchased goods set out below. These specific controls are rigidly enforced by the United States Naval authorities. Under their regulations personnel found abusing privileges would be subject to suspension in whole or in part (either indefinitely or for a stated period) of their commissary privileges and to strong disciplinary action. The following basic quotas apply:

Cigarettes: Limit of 400 cigarettes (or 1 lb tobacco or12 cuts of chewing tobacco) per week to authorised patrons. Sales are made only upon presentation of a valid Privilege Card and a Cigarette Ration Card issued by the Personnel Officer.
Spirituous Liquor:

item.label: (a)
item.para: personnel without dependants- 4 bottles of alcoholic beverage per month;

item.label: (b)
item.para: personnel with dependants in the area - 8 bottles of alcoholic beverage per month.
Sale is strictly by Ration Card and no representative or dependant may be designated to make purchases.
Expensive Items: Sales slips are made up and signed by patrons for any items in excess of $5 in value.

Petrol: Sold only to authorised patrons and only to vehicles with appropriate bumper decals. No more than 5 gallons of petrol is sold to patrons in separate containers. In addition to the above specific controls, purchase records are inspected at frequent intervals to detect any unusual purchases or violations of the regulations. There is provision for the placing of further merchandise rationing controls on any item in the event of evidence that it is being sold, bartered or traded to other than authorised patrons.

No. However, shortly after the commissary opened a minor abuse involving cigarettes did occur but steps in line with those described in answer to questions 6 to 8 were immediately taken to prevent a recurrence of the abuse.

Close liaison is maintained between the Civil Commissioner and the Commanding Officer to ensure that abuses do not occur and that measures for their prevention are adequate. No day to day customs or police supervision is carried out since the commissary operates within the station area which is effectively controlled by normal security measures. However the Department of Customs and Excise has a continuing role to ensure that all goods admitted at concessional tariff rates for specific purposes are not misused. The department exercises this function in regard to the sale of duty free goods from the facility at North West Cape. A recent inspection of the working of the commissary has been carried out by an official of the Department of Customs and Excise which is satisfied that there are no abuses of commissary privileges.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: Is it a fact that the new prescription limit of twenty-five sleeping tablets means that people who need these tablets will have to make additional visits to a doctor where they made one in the past?

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice:

item.para: Is it a fact that when the Bureau of Agricultural Economics analyses the economic justification of development projects, such as water conservation for irrigation of primary products, it values the output of primary products from the project at export parity prices and completely ignores the relevant domestic price of these products, while, at the same time, it values costs of the development project at the level of domestic costs, which include tariffs and similar measures affecting costs, and completely ignores import parity price of these costs?
If so, what is the reason for this difference in valuing inputs and outputs?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: In valuing the output of primary products from development projects the Bureau of Agricultural Economics must necessarily make assumptions as to the likely prices to be received for those products. It takes account of whether the product will be sold on the domestic market, or the export market, or both, likely price trends in such markets, including the possible effect on price of the additional supplies of those products from the development proposal being studied. In valuing the cost of the development project the Bureau of Agricultural Economics accepts the costs put forward by the construction authority. The assumptions made by the bureau are always set out in its published reports.
See answer to 1 above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: Is action being taken to force the Australian Medical Association to accept the 41,000 extra Australian pensioners into the pensioner medical service?
If so, what action is being taken?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.para: The pensioner medical service, ever since its inception, has been based on an agreement between the Government and the Australian Medical Association.
Having regard to the Government's policy on this matter and to the Commonwealth's constitutional powers, the question of compulsion does not arise.

Following the Australian Medical Association's deferment of a decision to admit the new group of pensioners into the pensioner medical service, discussions with the Association were initiated with a view to resolving the matter. These discussions are continuing.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice:

quote.para: What guarantee has the Australian Government that Australian wheat being sent to main land China is not being forwarded by mainland China to North Vietnam?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Australian Government does not exercise control over the ultimate destination of goods purchased by foreign buyers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Science, upon notice:

item.para: Have investigations by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation into the electronic precipitation of fly-ash been successful in preventing air pollution?
Could these methods be applied to eliminate the fly-ash nuisance caused by the burning of bagasse in sugar mill boilers?
Has any estimate been given of the cost of installing these soot-arrestors?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Education and Science has supplied the following information:

item.para: The method of electrostatic precipitation is widely used throughout the world for controlling emission of ash from smokestacks. The C.S.I.R.O. in collaboration with the Electricity Commission of New South Wales is investigating some special problems in the application of this method to coalfired power station boilers. Some progress has been made but there is a need for much more research.
The electrostatic precipitation method has been applied to controlling fly-ash from many different kinds of fuel but C.S.I.R.O. has not investigated its application to furnaces burning bagasse.

No estimate of the cost of installing electrostatic precipitators in sugar mill boiler furnaces has been made. The Sugar Research Institute, a cooperative research association subsidised by the Commonwealth, is investigating this problem.
